captions.text:
Well here it is, guys, the new 2015 S550 Ford
Mustang. It's finally my turn to get behind

the wheel. Now I think it's safe to say that
this has been one of the most closely watched
and carefully scrutinized cars of all time.

In the early renderings and spy photos, the
Internet rumors and speculation, all of course

leading up to the massive global unveiling.
That's right. For the first time ever, millions

of people worldwide will be able to enjoy
what over nine million Americans have been
enjoying for the last 50 years.

That's right, this thing is going global and
now it's my turn to give you guys a closer

look at the new Ford Mustang. The new styling,
the new independent rear suspension, those

quarter-mile times and dyno numbers. All to
answer, "Is this the best Mustang of all time?"

One of the most polarizing topics with the
new 2015 Ford Mustang is without a doubt the

styling. By now we've all heard the exhausting
comparisons to a two-door Ford Fusion or other

car brands and the argument that the 2015
Mustang just does not look like a Mustang.

Let's take a closer look to some of the exterior
lines and you can judge for yourself.

Up front, the car is very much a Ford Mustang,
from the trademark, shark-bite grill, reminiscent

of the '60s and early '70s Mustangs but also
some of the S197 Mustangs. Another part up

front here that is undeniably Mustang is the
daytime LED running lights, which do pay homage

to the headlight gills found on the first
Mustang.

I will say that is a little odd not seeing
the signature GT Mustang fog lights in the

grill for the first time in 10 years but on
the flip side, those functional hood vents

are back for 2015, albeit in a totally different
location.

Moving to the side of the car, you will notice
more Ford Mustang DNA. The sides of the sheet

metal have been sunken in, which is something
that has been passed on from generation to

generation. The A-pillar has actually been
pulled back with this car to accentuate the

longer hood line, which in the minds and the
eyes of the Ford designers, gave the car a
more powerful look.

Now that more powerful look does get helped
out thanks to the wider shoulders, which are

new for 2015. Without a doubt, one of the
biggest changes to the exterior styling is

the return of the fastback roof line for the
first time in decades.

Finishing in the rear of the car here, you
will notice the iconic tri-bar tail-lamps

are in place, along with the sequential taillights.
Now the '13 and '14 taillights, in my opinion,

might go down as one of the best ever on a
Mustang. While the '15 taillights are beautiful

in all their three-dimensional glory, they
are going to be graded on a very tough scale.

Noticing the sleek deckwood panel here, it
is devoid of that big gas cap for the first

time in 10 years on our GT, and the love-it-or-hate-it,
color-matched rear valance, which will definitely
have some help in the aftermarket.

While the exterior styling might be hit-or-miss
for some Ford Mustang fans, it's really hard

not to consider the newly-redesigned interior
a complete home run. Now as you may or may

not know, the name Mustang was originally
inspired not by a horse, but rather a legendary

World War II fighter plane, the P51 Mustang.
It's really no coincidence that this car has

a very cockpit- or aircraft-inspired feel
from the toggle switches, to the big, round,

analog gauges and even the ground-speed indicator
on the speedometer.

Now I will say that the interior has a very
nice touch of refinement. Everything that

looks to be metal, is, and it's really a night-and-day
difference from the SI97. Over 20 new pieces

of tech have found their way into the interior
here of the 2015.

Of course, old favorites like the productivity
screen and track hatch are back, which are

now standard on the GT by the way, but there
are some new things worth mentioning. I think

the biggest of which is the selectable driving
modes. On the modes here, you can select between

"Normal," "Sport Plus," "Track," and "Snow
and Wet" mode. Now by selecting these different

modes, it's going to alter three different
areas of your car's parameters: your stability

control, your steering feel, and your engine
parameters.

Another new feature here at the 2015 is the
launch control, which was previously only

available on the '13 and '14 Shelby GT500,
and of course, this lets you dial in your

optimal leave settings or launch settings
giving it your best launch.

Perhaps one of my favorite parts of the new
tech here at the 2015, which is standard on

all GTs, is the line lock. This just makes
big, smokey burnouts that much easier.

Finally here with all 2015 Mustangs, they
are all now keyless. You receive this key

fob, automatic remote start, which is a nice
touch and all cars do include remote and intelligent

access, meaning you can leave this fob in
your pocket, lock and unlock your car, and

even start the car with a push of a button,
now standard on all Mustangs.

Finally, last but not least, for all my Mustang
fans, I know you will appreciate this, the

cup holders have finally been moved over to
the side enough, where you can rest your arm

on the console comfortably and still shift
gears.

All right, the 5.0L Coyote motor is back for
2015 and it's better than ever. Now power

output is up to 435 horsepower, 400 pound
feet of torque at the crank, up 15 and 10

respectively from last year. This made for
382 horsepower and 359 pound feet of the torque
at the rear wheels on our DynoJet.

Now this motor borrows a ton from the previous
generation, Boss 302, such as the forged connecting

rods, some of the valve train components and
stiffer valve springs, with completely new

head castings, designed to flow much better
with the bumpier camshafts.

Now in my opinion, this motor should be well
more capable compared to the old motor as

far as total power output in the aftermarket.
Basically, this thing should be able to hold

a little bit more boost, a little bit more
power, without coming apart. Time will tell.

Both the 6R-80 automatic transmission and
the NTA2 manual transmission are back into

the 2015 with some improvements. Now the sometimes
finicky NT82 has gotten some improvements,

mainly the new clutch, along with some new
sink rows that Ford claims makes for a better

shifting experience and so far I would have
to agree with them.

However, that being said, an aftermarket shifter
should definitely be at the top of your mod

list, just to clean up some of the play found
here with the stock shifter. No big surprise
there.

Let's get to the big story, right. For the
first time in 50 years, all models of the

Ford Mustangs will come complete with an independent
rear suspension, a welcome change for many

owners and enthusiasts. Maybe not so much
for the hardcore drag racers. Now Ford's goal

with this car was to make it handle lust as
good, if not better, than the outgoing previous

Boss 302, and all tests they have done so
far have shown that to be the case.

Now again, first impression, this thing is
much flatter. Woo hoo! Just handles much better

than the previous stick-axle car by a long
shot. It's actually not even close.

As far as ride quality is concerned, well
this thing again is refined all the way. The

rear suspension obviously handles bumps much
better than a stick-axle car, especially when

going through turns or over uneven pavement.
Where a live rear axle would tend to pitch

and get unsettled, this thing just handles
it and keeps on trucking.

Ford actually had to totally redesign the
front suspension to keep up with the new rear.

In fact they have done so by doing a double
ball joint front suspension, complete with

a total new subframe underneath there, which
has made the way for some huge, huge brakes.
In fact, the biggest yet ever on a Mustang.

The performance packed GT, which I'm in right
now is now sporting six pistons, fixed-caliper

Brembos, with 15-inch, vented rotors. Now
that's pretty darn impressive but consider

the fact too that non-performance pack cars
now receive a solid brake upgrade in the form

of a four-piston caliper and rather large
brakes.

With all that said, is the 2015 Mustang the
best of all time? Well in my opinion, "yes."

It's not even close. Straight-line performance
aside, this car outperforms the previous generation

in just about every way. I mean, this car
just drives much better, handles completely

better than the S197, and the power delivery
is smooth and again, just more capable, and

I'll use that word, "refined" one more time
because this thing has gotten a lot of refinement
over the last year.

Lee Iaccoca once said that the Mustang will
"mean more things to more people than any

other automobile on the road." It never has
that been more true than with the 2015 Mustang,

with its 21st-century styling, powerful yet
diverse engine lineups, and now global availability,

people worldwide will be able to see what
makes Mustang an automotive icon.

I'm Justin. Thanks for watching. For all things
Mustang in 2015, keep it right here at americanmuscle.com.

title: 2015 Ford Mustang GT OFFICIAL Review – AmericanMuscle.com
